message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pruritic, erythematous, slightly raised annular patches with central clearing suggest a fungal infection, and the presence of hyphae when KOH is added to skin scrapings is sufficient for diagnosis. Option A describes the presentation of pityriasis rosea, not necessarily sufficient for diagnosis. Option C describes the presentation of erythema migrans, which is pathognomonic for Lyme disease but does not match the description of the skin lesion. Option D is also not relevant to the presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of pruritic, erythematous, slightly raised annular patches with central clearing on his back suggests a fungal infection. The KOH test can confirm the presence of hyphae, which is indicative of a fungal infection. The other options do not fit the presentation of a fungal infection. Option A is more suggestive of pityriasis rosea, option C is more suggestive of a viral exanthem, and option D is more suggestive of Lyme disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of pruritic, erythematous, slightly raised annular patches with central clearing on the back is indicative of a fungal infection, which can be confirmed with KOH preparation showing hyphae. Option A is suggestive of pityriasis rosea, which has a herald patch, but the lesions do not have to be along skin cleavage lines. Option C is indicative of erythema migrans in Lyme disease, which presents as a single expanding rash rather than multiple annular patches. Option D is also not relevant to the presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the skin lesion is suggestive of a fungal infection like tinea corporis. The presence of hyphae when KOH is added to skin scrapings is sufficient for the diagnosis. Option A describes the presentation of pityriasis rosea, not tinea corporis. Option C describes the presentation of erythema migrans, which is associated with Lyme disease. Option D is unrelated to the presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the skin lesions, especially with central clearing and slightly raised annular patches, suggests the diagnosis of ringworm. The presence of hyphae when KOH is added to skin scrapings can confirm the diagnosis. The other options suggest other dermatological conditions such as pityriasis rosea, scabies, and Lyme disease, but they do not fit with the presentation described in the question stem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of pruritic, erythematous, slightly raised annular patches with central clearing on the back is suggestive of tinea corporis, which can be confirmed with the presence of hyphae on skin scrapings examined under a microscope after adding KOH. History of a herald patch and lesions along skin cleavage lines suggest pityriasis rosea, symmetrical distribution on bilateral extremities progressing proximally suggests either psoriasis or erythema migrans (a rash associated with Lyme disease), but neither of these options match the presentation given.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of pruritic, erythematous, slightly raised annular patches with central clearing on his back is consistent with the appearance of a fungal infection, specifically a dermatophyte infection. Adding KOH to skin scrapings to look for hyphae is a common diagnostic test for dermatophyte infections. The other options do not match the description of the lesion and would not be sufficient to make the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the skin lesions suggests that the most likely diagnosis is ringworm infection. The presence of hyphae when KOH is added to skin scrapings is sufficient to confirm this diagnosis. History of recent herald patch and lesions along skin cleavage lines suggest pityriasis rosea, symmetrical distribution on bilateral extremities progressing proximally suggests erythema multiforme, and history of time spent in a Lyme-endemic region suggests Lyme disease, but none of these are related to the skin lesions described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the skin lesions suggests tinea corporis or ringworm infection. The presence of hyphae when KOH is added to skin scrapings is sufficient for diagnosis. Option A is more consistent with pityriasis rosea, option C with erythema migrans, and option D with Lyme disease, none of which are the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The skin lesion described in the question, specifically the presence of pruritic, erythematous, slightly raised annular patches with central clearing are classic signs of tinea corporis, a fungal infection of the skin. Presence of hyphae when KOH is added to skin scrapings is sufficient to confirm the diagnosis. History of a herald patch and lesions along skin cleavage lines suggest pityriasis rosea, symmetrical distribution on bilateral extremities progressing proximally suggest a viral exanthem, and history of time spent in a Lyme-endemic region suggests Lyme disease, none of which fit the clinical picture described in the question.
